title: The YASGUI Family of SPARQL Clients

author: Laurens Rietveld, Faculty of Sciences, Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU)

segmentation: OK, my name is largely self and I'm going to talk to you about the ASCII family of Sparkle clients.
Just to get a feel on how many people know you're screwy, could you show your hand if you?
OK, so this is a good thing.
I'll try to tell you something new, hopefully and for the other people.
I will show you how.
School works as well.
So first about the history of your school.
Yes, he is driven by frustration, so it's frustration driven research.
I started my PC and I wanted to get to know Sparkle, learn it's a bit and try out some sparkle endpoints.
An all I was left with.
Are simple text areas.
Um and the frustrations I had for specifically.
Where can I find sparkle endpoints?
Is there a nice place with some URLs that I can easily try out?
Which tools can be used to access them?
Most Parker endpoints had a interface on top of it, often a simple text area.
But some of them didn't.
For instance, 4 store Apple store.
Um?

And by the way, some of these tools I had to install locally, which is another barrier to do right, and some of these tools were web apps, but they had the disadvantage that you couldn't access any sparkle endpoints.
Some spark endpoints don't allow cross origin JavaScript querying, so it turned out that none of the tools were able to access any sparkle endpoints.
Another big frustration was that if I wrote a sparkle query, the only way I could test whether my query was syntactically valid and in my early times they often weren't, was by executing the query.
And the problem was if I executed the query I got a often nonsensical error message back.
So I couldn't figure out why my query was invalid.
An A simple problem.
I kept copy pasting the RDF prefix or prefix or whatever.
So for those of you who forgot, this is the area prefix.

Assist these people more in accessing spoken inputs so the first thing I did was I.
If the web app I didn't want to have locally installed application an, I wanted to have similar features that regular programmers are used to with.

I'd East development environments such as syntax highlighting, would also syntax checking whenever you make an error, it should show that your query is wrong and it should, and it shoots notify you what particularly is wrong in your query and it should be able to access any sparkle endpoint.
So even endpoints running on your Internet, localhost endpoints that are not cross origin JavaScript enabled.
The way I do this is that if your school, we can access the sparkle endpoints directly via JavaScript.
It does and if it counts then it will use a proxy.
And of course I want to have the auto completion features at regular IDE serve as well, such as a prefix or the completion and property in class or the completion.
And I want to make it easy to find the sparkle endpoints that might be interesting, so I guess everybody knows that the pedia URL.
But other than that, it's difficult finding sparkle endpoints.
So had a pre populated list of sparkle inputs in there as well.
And this is what I ended up making.
This is the first iteration of your Scooby and it has all the features that I described.
But there were some problems making this, and some of these problems are limitations.
Still remain.
So the sparkle standard is pretty nice, so there's a specification for the Sparkle protocol Sparkle queries itself.

Obviously the Sparkle resultset format, but one thing that I forgot to do is specify what an endpoint should give back whenever there is an error, either a query error or something that sparkle endpoints simply can't do because of its capabilities.
So this inconsistent error reporting some endpoints return link data.
Some endpoints return plain text in the response bodies, some of them return plain text in header somewhere.
You do some munging and some heuris tics, too.
Handle these errors gracefully.
Another problem, at least in the at the time when I made this first version, was that there were unknown endpoints capabilities, so I could know beforehand whether an endpoint supported 1.0 or 1.1.
Or which features of 1.1 it's supported, but Luckily this has been improved lately with lots of spoken input specifications that you can query and stuff like that.
But in general, a limitation of your school that is still there today is that I have to develop for the lowest common denominator so.
The goal of your school is to work on any sparkle endpoints.
And ideally I would use the sparkle endpoints to give away better user experience, for instance for.
Auto completing properties.
Ideally you want to send the sparkle endpoint asking hey what kind of properties do you have?
But this turned out to be.
This query stood out to be something that can simply crash Parker endpoints, which isn't something I would like to be responsible for so.
So I had to develop the lowest common denominator an leave outs.
These kind of features that can utilize spoken input themselves more.
So I made this first version and then developers came up to me and said, listen, this looks really nice.
I want to use this on my end point.
Or they had ideas on how to render the sparkle results differently.
They didn't want a table, but they want another visualization.
Or they wanted to reuse.
Yes GUI in one of their tools.
So that's why I made the most recent version.
There's a complete rewrite of your school and it's actually split into three chunks.
So we have yuska, yet another Sparkle query editor.

This is pretty valuable query set because the query looks we otherwise have a query logs from thedbpedia.org and a couple of other sparkle endpoints that's published these, and they have lots of queries executed by applications in there, and there are some queries actually written by people who press the query button and get a result right, but it's very difficult to differentiate.
Between both an.

How complex are queries that we developers make and what a typical patterns with a typical task?
For instance that we perform.
But we can also use this queries to get more of an overview on linked data.
So what are the popular endpoints which is impossible to know based on server logs alone?
Because all these endpoints would have to cooperate, obviously.
But I've got these more lesser funnel that we can use as a few for linked data.
And again here I could see how complex the queries are that people typically execute on spark endpoints, and for instance, how much is Federation used, which isn't a lot.
So.
I'm currently still pretty much in it, so very much in active development, so if you got to open tripoligithub.com slash open 3 Princess, you're screwy.

So just to come back to your comments about having to support the lowest common denominator is that holding you back in any way from my 'cause I think you mentioned things like being able to do more sophisticated things with drop down so that kind of stuff where you kind of holding back from that because you do want to keep supporting those denominators.
Are you ever tempted to kind of like start saying?
Well, you've got to be running a certain version of?
Endpoints are going to be able to provide some facilities and I don't know you know what your thoughts are on that.
Yeah, so I'm.
I'm really holding back on this so in practice.

So I do so it's pretty easy to configure all of these components, so I've got a couple of GitHub Gists that show if you would really want property autocompletion based on the spot in point alone, you can simply copy paste this code and essentially extends just GUI to have this behavior, but the defaults are mostly pretty simple.
So my question is, does Yaz GUI have support for reasoning or and if not, do you plan to include that at some point?
No it doesn't.
Then we don't plan on supporting it, so we're really offloading all the query capabilities to the sparkle endpoints so we only sending it and rendering the results and that's it.
